Cardiopulmonary Effects of Tobacco and Related Substances
III. Pulmonary Vascular Effects of Cigarette Smoke and Nicotine MILAN SAMANEK, MD, AND DOMINGO, M. AVIADO, MD, PHILADELPHIA
THE CONSIDERATION of the pul- monary circulation, the third and last com- ponent of the cardiopulmonary system, has been postponed until now because of its strategie location. The dependency of the pulmonary circulation on the performance of the heart and bronchial-alveolar system requires that the actions of tobacco on the latter two areas must be completed prior to the investigations on the former. Manifesta- tions of the effects of tobacco on the pul- monary circulation may possibly be secondary to the primary effects on the bronchial airways,14 heart,5 and coronary circulation . so that these must be excluded before any direct action of tobacco on the pulmonary blood vessels can be identified.
Methods
Twenty mongrel dogs under morphine (2 mg/kg ) and chloralose (70 mg/kg) anesthesia were used. A bronchospirometer tube was inserted for measure- ments of bronchomotor response of left lower lobe separately from all the other lobes. The method has been reported in detail in an earlier paper.' Three groups of experiments were performed :
Group 1 .-- Inflow Perfusion of the Left Lower Lobe (Dogs No. 1 to 7) : The left lower lobe was exposed by a left (fourth intercostal) thoracotomy. The artery to this lobe was ligated and cannulated peripherally for perfusion with blood from the dog's own femoral vessel or inferior vena cava (Fig 1).
The central end of the same lobar artery was catheterized to measure pressure of all the other lobes which were intact and supplied by the animal's own right ventricle, One carotid artery was catheterired for recording sortie blood pressure. These Statham transducers were used to measure Subtihed for publication Jon 21. 1966; accepted Feb 26
From the Department of Pharmacology, University of Pennsylvania, School of Medicine.
Reprint requests to Department of Pharmacology. School of Medicine, University of Pennsylvania, Phila- delphia, 19104 (Dr. Avindo).
aortic blood pressure, pulmonary arterial pressure. and perfusion pressure. In some dogs, the left atrium was catheterized via an opening in its ap- pendage to measure atrial pressure by a fourth transdecer. The stimulus consisted of administra- tion of cigarette smoke to the inlet of the pump ventilating the left lower lobe, or of injection of nicotine directly into the tubing perfusing blood into the left lower lobe. Most dogs were studied initially after combined bilateral cervical vagotomy and intravenous injection of atropine sulfate (1 mg/kg).
GROUP 2 .- Complete Perfusion of the Left Lower Lobe (Dogs No. 8 to 15) : In addition to the can- mulation of the left lower Inbe reported above, the

Fig 1 .- Scheme of lung perfusion Right lower half below dotted diagonal line: Inflow perfusion of the left lower lobe showing perfusion pump and manometer (M ) to supply lotar artery with blood derived from femoral artery, vein, or inferior vena cava (not shown). Left upper holf: Cannulation of the lobar vein to collect perfusate in an outside reservoir which in turn is source of blood perfusing the artery.
Arch Environ Health-Vol 12, June 1966

THE CONSIDERATION of the pul- monary circulation, the third and last com- ponent of the cardiopulmonary system, has been postponed until now because of its strategie location. The dependency of the pulmonary circulation on the performance of the heart and bronchial-alveolar system requires that the actions of tobacco on the latter two areas must be completed prior to the investigations on the former. A bronchospirometer tube was inserted for measure- ments of bronchomotor response of left lower lobe separately from all the other lobes. The method has been reported in detail in an earlier paper.'
